comments.body:
Stylistically, I would do `timeout(60.seconds) { ... suite ... }`

**EDIT**: In fact, I think timeout strategy should be on `Runner` and _not_ on the test, because there shouldn't be 2 ways to do this.

/cc @adamgfraser

@jdegoes @adamgfraser 
If we move it to `Runner`, that means we couldn't use `DefaultTestRunner` and `DefaultRunnableSpec` if we want to have a different one from the default. We would have to make a custom `Runner` and then a custom `RunnableSpec`, is that right?

@jdegoes @ghostdogpr What if we made `TimeoutStrategy` a subtype of `TestAspect`? `TestAspect.timeout` is already isomorphic with `TestStrategy.Error`. `TestStrategy.Ignore` is a no-op, so that would be equivalent to `TestAspect.identity`, which we don't have but could easily add. So the only thing would be whether we could implement `Warn` as a `TestAspect`. I remember when I worked on the original PR I thought we couldn't for some reason but I think maybe I reworked it after that because the type signatures look the same. 

That would go a long way to unify things because then everything would be a `TestAspect` so at worst there are two different ways to add a `TestAspect` versus having this `TestAspect.timeout` and then `TimeoutStrategy` that are completely different things. I'm a little concerned with moving it to `Runner` because I think that makes it more difficult for us to have a default timeout policy that is also easily override by a user who is just extending `DefaultRunnableSpec` But maybe if we do that unification it addresses your concerns?
